digitalObject.dc:title: Plan and drawing of exterior of the Sultan Hasan Madrasa-Mausoleum-Mosque Complex, Cairo.
digitalObject.dc:description: The Complex of Sultan Hasan was built between 1356 and 1363, and included a madrasa, congregational mosque, and mausoleum. The free-standing complex, which had a monumental domed mausoleum flanked by minarets, only one of which survives, is located in a prominent position below the Citadel, toward which the monumental portal is oriented. The muqarnas-hood portal occupies the entire length of the façade. The height of the exterior walls and the arrangement of the windows give the facades a strongly vertical emphasis.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Islamic architecture--Egypt--Cairo--Designs and plans.
Architecture, Mameluke--Egypt--Cairo--Designs and plans.
Mosques--Egypt--Cairo--Designs and plans.
digitalObject.ac:name: amay02

digitalObject.dc:title: Court of the Lions, Alhambra.
digitalObject.dc:description: Sultan Muhammad V built the Palace of the Lions' most celebrated feature in the 14th century, a fountain with a complex hydraulic system consisting of a marble basin on the backs of twelve carved stone lions situated at the intersection of two water channels that form a cross in the rectilinear courtyard. An arched covered patio encircles the courtyard and displays fine stucco carvings held up by a series of slender columns. Two decorative pavilions protrude into the courtyard on an East-West (cross-axial) in the chahar bagh style, accentuating the royal spaces behind them.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Islamic architecture--Spain--Granada.
Courtyards--Spain--Granada.
Lion in art.
Architecture--Spain--Islamic influences.
Water and architecture.
digitalObject.ac:name: amay02

digitalObject.dc:title: Muqarnas Dome, Hall of the Abencerrajes, Palace of the Lions, Alhambra.
digitalObject.dc:description: To the West of the courtyard in the Palace of the Lions is the Muqarnas Chamber, which may have functioned as an antechamber and was near the original entrance to the palace. It takes its name from the intricately carved system of brackets called "muqarnas" that hold up the vaulted ceiling. Two decorative pavilions protrude into the courtyard on an East-West (cross-axial) in the chahar bagh style, accentuating the royal spaces behind them Stucco ornament or muqarnas is suspended from the dome. This turns the ceiling into an incomprehensible eight pointed star through the use of squinches. s a form of architectural ornamented vaulting, the "geometric subdivision of a squinch, or cupola, or corbel, into a large number of miniature squinches, producing a sort of cellular structure", sometimes also called "honeycomb" vaults from their resemblance to these. They are used for domes, and especially half-domes in entrances and apses, mostly in traditional Islamic and Persian architecture.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Islamic domes--Spain--Granada.
Vaults (Architecture)--Spain--Granada.
Islamic architecture--Spain--Granada.
Architecture--Spain--Islamic influences.
digitalObject.ac:name: amay02

digitalObject.dc:title: Tile Mosaic Mihrab.
digitalObject.dc:description: This prayer niche, or mihrab, is in the style of the Timurids, who were known for using bright blue and white colors. It was originally set into the qibla wall of a theological school in Isfahan, now known as the Madrasa Imami, built just after the collapse of the Ilkhanid dynasty. The mihrab was created by joining a myriad of cut glazed tiles to produce its intricate arabesque and calligraphic designs. The inscription is of the five pillars of Islam.
Location created: Madrasa Imami, Isfahan, Iran.
Current location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Mihrabs--Iran--Iṣfahān.

digitalObject.dc:title: Shah-I Zinda Funerary Complex.
digitalObject.dc:description: The Shah-i Zinda (lit. "the Living King") is a funerary complex, located on the south side of the Afrasiyab hill in the city of Samarqand. The focal point of the complex is the shrine of Qusam b. Abbas, a cousin of the Prophet Muhammad, who was reportedly beheaded on a site near Samarqand's wall during the seventh-century Arab conquests of Transoxania. Ascending from the southern slope of the Afrasiayab hill, the Shah-i Zinda complex consists of a narrow 200-meter alley or corridor, lined with some 40 funerary buildings, nearly half of which were revealed in excavations. The most striking aspect of the Shah-i Zinda is its exquisite tilework. The decorative programs of the funerary buildings display a wide range of motifs, materials and techniques.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Sepulchral monuments--Uzbekistan--Samarqand.
Tile facades--Uzbekistan--Samarqand.

digitalObject.dc:title: Mina'I Bowl with Bahram Gur and Azada.
digitalObject.dc:description: Some of the mina'i ceramics illustrate stories from the Persian epic, the Shahnama, predating its earliest surviving illustrated manuscripts by nearly a century. This bowl depicts the episode of Prince Bahram Gur hunting with Azada, his favorite concubine. Azada challenges Bahram Gur to a hunting feat, but when he succeeds, she pities the slain gazelles and reproaches him. In anger, he tramples her under his camel's feet. The painter has conflated two different moments into one scene.
Current location: Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.
Medium: Stonepaste; polychrome in-glaze and overglaze painted on opaque monochrome glaze (mina'i)
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Islamic pottery.
Color in the ceramic industries.
Art pottery.
Stoneware.
Kings and rulers in art.

digitalObject.ac:name: amay02

digitalObject.dc:title: Baptistery of St. Louis.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Muḥammad ibn al-Zayn, active approximately 1290-approximately 1310.
digitalObject.dc:description: This basin, known at the "Baptistery of St. Louis", was made in Mamluk Syria or Egypt during the first half of the fourteenth century. On the outer surface, the decorative panels, interspersed with roundels, depict running animals in the upper and lower bands. The center shows scenes of horsemen flanked by attendants, soldiers and falcons. Inside the basin, four oblong panels depict two hunting scenes, then two battle scenes. A shortage of silver prompted the development of inlaid brasswork which used precious silver sparingly. Date created: c. 1300 CE; Location created: Syria or Egypt; Current location: Musee du Louvre, Paris.
Medium: Hammered brass, gold, silver, and niello inlay.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Islamic art metal-work.
Niello.
Bronze fonts, Medieval.
Basins (Containers)

digitalObject.ac:name: amay02

digitalObject.dc:title: Qur'an Frontispiece.
digitalObject.dc:description: The Qur'an to which this page belonged was donated in 1369 by Sultan Shaban to the madrasa established by his mother. In this frontispiece, the ornate design was possibly based on the geometric architectural structures common to the region. Its resemblance to court carpets was not coincidental, since designers often worked in more than one medium.
Current location: National Library, Cairo MS. 7.
Medium: Ink, pigments, and gold on paper.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Islamic illumination of books and manuscripts.
Frontispiece.
Qurʼan--Illustrations.
Islamic decoration and ornament.
digitalObject.dcadesc:persname: Shaʻbān ibn Ḥusayn, Sultan of Egypt and Syria, 1353-1377.
digitalObject.ac:name: amay02

digitalObject.dc:title: Yusuf Fleeing Zulayhka.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Bihzād, active 16th century.
digitalObject.dc:description: In this miniature painting, which appears in a manuscript of 13th-century poet Sa'di's Bustan ("Orchard"), depicts a story from the Qur'an. Zulayhka, the wife of a chief of Misr, becomes infatuated with Yusuf, the chief's personal attendant. They became more intimate until Yusuf remembers that God can see everything. He refuses Zulayhka and as he leaves the room, she catches him by the garment, tearing a piece of it. She then produces the torn cloth as evidence to her husband and accuses Yusuf of rape.
Current location: National Library, Cairo, Egypt.
Medium: Ink and pigments on paper.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Islamic miniature painting--Afghanistan--Herat.
Islamic illumination of books and manuscripts--Afghanistan--Herat.
Yūsuf and Zulaykhā.
digitalObject.ac:name: amay02

digitalObject.dc:title: The Mosque of Sultan Selim, Edirine.
digitalObject.dc:creator: Sinan, Mimar, 1489 or 1490-1588.
digitalObject.dc:description: This mosque was built by the Sultan Selim II, the son of Süleyman the Magnificent, between 1568 and 1574. Architect Sinan worked for the Sultan. Located in the Balkans, within the European lands of the Ottoman Empire, Edirne had been a capital of the Ottoman Empire in the 15th century before Istanbul and was effectively the second city of the Empire through the 17th century. The mosque's nearly square prayer hall is approached through a porticoed courtyard, making the central block of the complex rectangular, with four minarets and large dome. The mosque was highly influenced by Byzantine models, particularly Hagia Sophia.
digitalObject.dcadesc:subject: Architecture, Ottoman--Turkey--Edirne.
Islamic architecture--Turkey--Edirne.
Mosques--Turkey--Edirne.
